Comment: A bad move; Black voluntarily blocks his d-pawn to defend his e-pawn.  This makes it hard for him to develop freely (the white sq bishop will have to come to b7 after ...b6 - more lost time).  ...Nc6 is a natural and good move.

Ok; but given Black's lacklustre start, 3.c3, aiming to play d4 with a massive centre looks more ambitious.
Stops the white knight coming to d5, but at the cost of now blocking the c6 sq for his b8 knight.  Not a great start by Black.  Better would be ...Nc6, hoping for the best.
A better bet would be 4.d4! Then, if ...exd4 5.Qxd4 (attacking the misplaced bishop on d6) and, if Black protects with 5...Qf6, 6. e5 forks bishop and queen.
Because White is not challenging the centre (4. d3), Black is allowed to get away with a whole series of inconsequential pawn moves intended to hinder White but at the cost of lots of tempi (moves).

Realising his earlier error, Black redirects the bishop - abandonning the e5 pawn to its fate (having played d3, White need not worry about ...Qe7 after 6. Nxe5, since his e4-pawn is protected).  Now, if he can get in ...d6, Black may stand ok.

Again, perfectly alright but just Nxe5 is simpler. If Black had replied ...Qa5 (seemingly attacking both the knight on e5 and threatening to take twice on c3) White has the nice interposing move 7. Nc4! attacking the Black Queen.   6. 0-0 would also have been more enterprising, not fearing the doubled pawns after ...Bxc3  7.bxc3 when White could play d4 supported by the new pawn at c3.
Another curious pawn move.  Hard to see what it's aimed at.  Again, the pawn at e5 is still undefended...
Verging on suicide.  Black goes for a k-side pawn storm with only one piece developed.

Putting the question to the bishop.  10. a4 would also have been interesting - threatening the b5 pawn  and if 10...bxa4 11.Rxa4 attacking the bishop.

White has a clear advantage now.  He's nearly completed his develpoment and has an akward pin on the f6 knight.
White has a clear advantage now.  He's nearly completed his develpoment and has an akward pin on the f6 knight.

Better was just 12. Re1, aiming for 13. Bf1 and then 14. e5! breaking open the centre.  White had no need to fear the further advance of the b-pawn as the Ra8 is undenfended after 12...b4  13. axb4 ...13 axb4??  Simlarly, if Black is hoping to play ...a4, why not let him?  With Black's king about to get killed there's no need to think about the endgame...

Getting the pawn centre but without first protecting e4.  Re1 followed by Bf1 would have allowed a subsequent d5 without material loss.

(?) Horrid move - blocking in that lovely bishop.  The d-pawn was already heavily defended.  Or, why not open up further with 19. d5!? (revealing an attack on the Qf6 from the b2 bishop and simultaneously attacking the bishop on e6).  After 19 ...Qxb2,  20. dxe6 and it's nearly over - so vulnerable is B's king.
taking the chance to get to (relative) safety.

(?) Why?  This bad move weakens the white squares around White's king when Black's white-sq bishop is still on the board - hardly ever a good plan.  It also ties W's queen to the defence of the f3 knight (no longer pawn-protected and threatened by B's Qf6).
Black could now have taken advantage of White's last to force a draw: 20...Bb3 (attacking the queen) 21. Qe2 (White must stay protecting the f3 sq) 21...Bc4  22. Qc2 and 22...Bb3 again etc.
